Abstract: Concerns have been raised over the spread of transgenic DNA by horizontal gene transfer. One main factor determining the success of horizontal gene transfer is its tendency to recombine. This paper examines the safety implication of recent revelations on the recombination hotspot of the cauliflower mosaic viral (CaMV) promoter, which is in practically all current transgenic crops released commercially or undergoing field trials. As a precautionary measure, we strongly recommend that all transgenic crops containing CaMV 35S or similar promoters which are recombinogenic should be immediately withdrawn from commercial production or open field trials. All products derived from such crops containing transgenic DNA should also be immediately withdrawn from sale and from use for human consumption or animal feed. © Scandinavian University Press 1999.

Title: Chromosome aberrations produced by 5-bromodeoxyuridine with concurrent exposure to long wavelength UV in Zea mays root tip cells
Source title: Canadian Journal of Genetics and Cytology
Affiliations: Dept. Plant Scis, Univ. West. Ontario, London, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Verma, R.S., Dept. Plant Scis, Univ. West. Ontario, London, Canada; Cummins, J.E., Dept. Plant Scis, Univ. West. Ontario, London, Canada; Walden, D.B., Dept. Plant Scis, Univ. West. Ontario, London, Canada
Abstract: The influence of bromodeoxyuridine (BrUrdR) on the pattern and level of chromosome damage in Zea mays L. root dip cells is described. In some experiments long wavelength ultraviolet light was employed to convert the bromodeoxyuridine in DNA to its photoproduct. BrUrdR treatment produced a marked decrease in the mitotic index and a high proportion of the mitotic cells bore chromosome damage. Following a BrUrdR treatment of 5 hr the proportion of damaged cells increased from 20% to 60% during the 20 hr following treatment; then the proportion decreased sharply to less than 20%. Root tips treated as above followed by an exposure to long wavelength ultraviolet radiation (UV) had a proportion of damaged cells (80% at 20 hr) only slightly greater than those not exposed to UV up to 20 hr after treatment. Unlike the unirradiated BrUrdR substituted root tips, the proportion of damaged cells ramined high 25 hr after treatment. Furthermore, the spectrum of chromosome aberrations differed between irradiated and unirradiated BrUrdR substituted cells. Root tips exposed to long wavelength UV alone showed some damage that was limited to a stage in the cell cycle of irradiated root tips. Analysis of the BrUrdR treated corn DNA by cesium chloride density centrifugation showed that BrUrdR substitution for thymidine in DNA was extensive. Further experiments demonstrated that a large BrUrdR pool was not carried into the rounds of replication following BrUrdR removal from the medium. Nevertheless a small pool of halogenated pyrimidine was observable after BrUrdR removal from the medium.

Title: Transcription and translation of the sex message in the smut fungus, Ustilago violacea. I. The effect of ultraviolet light
Affiliations: Dept. Plant Sci., Univ. West. Ontario, London, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Day, A.W., Dept. Plant Sci., Univ. West. Ontario, London, Ont., Canada; Cummins, J.E., Dept. Plant Sci., Univ. West. Ontario, London, Ont., Canada
Abstract: Cells of opposite mating type, a 1 and a 2, of the anther smut fungus, Ustilago violacea assemble a conjugation tube after about 3-4 hr of mating on nutrient free media. Low doses of ultraviolet light (u.v.) delay but do not prevent conjugation in wild type strains if given in the first 2-3 hr of mating. However, irradiation later than this period has little effect and conjugation proceeds normally. The u.v. effect is photoreactivable and it is concluded that u.v. induces dimers which affect transcription of specific messenger RNA molecules needed for conjugation ('sex message'). Evidence suggests that the dimers may cause mistranscription rather than the complete prevention of transcription. The effect of u.v. on conjugation in reciprocal crosses of u.v. sensitive and wild type strains indicates clearly that both partners must complete transcription of sex messages in order to conjugate. Inactivation of either partner before transcription prevents conjugation, but conjugation proceeds when either cell is inactivated after transcription of the sex messages has occurred. These results suggest that a mutual and reciprocal exchange of information between the 2 mating types occurs prior to the assembly of the conjugation tube.

Abstract: The uptake and incorporation of adenine and uracil during the cell cycle of the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe in normal growth was measured by grain counting in autoradiographs and by bulk counting in synchronous cultures. This is probably due to a change in the base composition of the RNA and not to changes in uptake rate or pool size. About half the step-down RNA was found in the cytoplasm after a short pulse label. © 1969.

Abstract: The nearest neighbor frequencies of RNA synthesized in nuclei isolated from plasmodia of Physarum polycephalum at different stages of the cell cycle were investigated. The relative frequencies of dinucleotides, beginning with guanylic and cytidylic acids, increased during the cell cycle, whereas dinucleotides beginning with adenylic and uridylic acids decreased. Since dinucleotide frequencies are a measure of the RNA nucleotide sequence, there was a qualitative shift in DNA transcription from predominantly adenylic and thymidylic acid-rich DNA molecules or molecular regions to guanylic and cytidylic acid-rich DNA molecules or molecular regions as the cell cycle progressed. These nearest neighbor frequency analyses also showed that the RNA nucleotides were not randomly arranged in the polynucleotide chains and that only a limited portion of the total nuclear DNA was transcribed. These results suggest that DNA transcription follows an ordered temporal sequence during the cell cycle and also show that mitosis must provide a means of reinitiating DNA transcription at the starting point in a temporal cycle. © 1967.

Abstract: An investigation of adenine uptake and pool formation in the fission yeast yielded the following results. 1. 1. Adenine was taken up from the medium at a rapid initial rate. The rate decayed to a constant value per unit mass 15-20 min after exposure of a culture to adenine. 2. 2. The final size of the intracellular pool of adenine metabolites appeared to be independent of the adenine level in the medium through a wide range of adenine levels. 3. 3. Adenine uptake was strongly dependent on glucose. 4. 4. The concentration-velocity response of adenine uptake followed simple enzyme kinetics. The observed Km was 0.33 μg/ml (2.45 × 10-6M). The observed V was 10-8 μg/min per cell. Several purine bases and ribonucleisides served as competitive inhibitors of adenine uptake. 5. 5. Prefilling with adenine resulted in a non-competitive inhibition of adenine uptake. Prefilling with several purine bases and ribonucleosides also resulted in a non-competitive inhibition of adenine uptake. 6. 6. Chromatography of the pool components labeled by adenine showed that AMP and inosine were labeled most rapidly under nornal conditions. Prefiling decreased the relative amount of label in inosine while pulse and chase experiments yielded relatively more label in inosine than AMP. The results of these experiments suggest that adenine uptake is mediated by a specific transport system and an accumulation of particular pool components may be important factors in regulating the flow of adenine into the cell. A scheme relating adenine influx, the purine pools and RNA synthesis is suggested. © 1967.

Abstract: Measurements were made with an integrating interference microscope of the total dry mass of a number of intact cells from growing populations of the fission yeast, Schizosaccharomyces pombe. The increase in total dry mass during the cell cycle was calculated from these data, using a known relation between cell length and stage in the cycle. Similar measurements were made on cells from the same populations which had been extracted by freezing and acid. The size of the acid-soluble pool was obtained from the difference between these measurements. The results, which confirmed earlier experiments, showed that the rate of growth of total dry mass remained constant through the cycle whereas the rate of synthesis of the major macromolecular components increased. The relative size of the pool fluctuated, reaching a maximum in the middle of the cycle. The mean size of the pool (pool dry mass/total dry mass) was 17.9 per cent. This was in good agreement with the gravimetric figure of 16 per cent. © 1964.

Abstract: Nucleate and anucleate half cells of Amoeba proteus were labelled with [32P]orthophosphate and the distribution of 32P among the labelled nucleotides was examined. Both nucleate and anucleate half cells were capable of incorporating orthophosphate into RNA. It was further shown that the radioactivity was primarily associated with 2′,3′-nucleotides following alkaline degradation of the labelled RNA, ruling out the possibility of a nucleotide-binding phenomenon. Finally the half cells were fractionated by centrifugation and the distribution of 32P in RNA of these fractions was analyzed. The fractionation experiments led us to conclude that RNA associated with the microsomes contains much of the label in nucleate and anucleate half cells. The RNA of the microsomes has similar distributions of 32P in both nucleate and anucleate half cells and these distributions were similar to the total half-cell distributions of 32P.
